ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Left hemisphere infarct
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: History of stroke with aphasia; CT confirms extensive left-sided lesion; central tests show right ear deficit and left-sided electrode effect.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Noise-induced hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss consistent with history of military noise exposure.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To evaluate the extent of the brain lesion given the history of stroke.
To investigate the effects of the lesion on auditory potentials.
To assess central auditory processing and dichotic listening abilities.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: The evaluation reveals a mixed picture of peripheral and central deficits. Peripheral testing shows bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss. Central testing demonstrates profound deficits consistent with the extensive left hemisphere infarction seen on CT, characterized by a severe right-ear deficit on dichotic digits and a clear electrode effect on P300 testing (poorer responses over the left hemisphere).

tests.name: Radiology (CT)
tests.result_summary: Recent CT showed extensive involvement of the left insula, posterior-inferior frontal lobe, temporal lobe, internal capsule, and lateral ventricle.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Bilateral high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss commencing at 2000 Hz. Low frequencies (250-1000 Hz) are normal. Left ear shows a steeper slope at 4000 Hz (90 dB HL).

tests.name: Auditory Evoked Potentials (Late/P300)
tests.result_summary: Demonstrated an 'electrode effect' where the C3 (left) electrode provided poorer results (reduced amplitude/delayed latency) than C4 (right). Also showed a 'laterality effect' with better responses for Left Ear stimulation.

tests.name: Dichotic Digits
tests.result_summary: Marked right ear deficit (8%) with left ear scores slightly below normal (80%).

proposed_items: Communication strategies favoring the left ear
counseling_actions: Explain that hearing difficulties are a combination of peripheral loss and central processing deficits from the stroke
Discuss that hearing aids may help audibility but may not fully resolve clarity issues due to central deficits
Recommend favoring the left ear for communication as it is the better processing ear
Highlight that good low-frequency hearing allowed for valid P300 testing

escalation.rationale_short: Research evaluation of a chronic, stable condition.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing status and communication strategies.
